SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Complicating events and unusual presentations associated with intracranial abscess are rare but potentially fatal conditions
This study was undertaken to shed light on the unusual complications and presentations of intracranial abscess treated at a single institution
METHODS: We retrospectively reviewed 116 cases of intracranial abscesses that were treated at our institution over the last 10 years and identified 11 (9.4%) cases with unusual complications

RESULTS: These complications consisted of (1) rupture within the abscess, (2) hemorrhage into the abscess, (3) hemispheric infarction due to ICA thrombosis, (4) acute visual loss due to pituitary abscess, (5) acute neurologic deterioration due to rapid gas formation within the abscess, (6) acute hydrocephalus, (7) trigeminal neuralgia, (8) fungal abscess developing secondary to intracranial extension of a temporal bone tumor, (9) Cryptococcus abscess with different morphology, (10) pontine infarction, and (11) sigmoid sinus thrombosis
Sinusitis accompanied 8 (72.7%) of the cases, and there were 5 (45.4%) mortalities
Culture results were unyielding in 4 patients, whereas Streptococcus species were identified in 4 and fungi in the rest
CONCLUSION: Intracranial abscesses and their complications still continue to be challenging entities in the neurosurgical practice
Our experience may provide an informational source for those who are taking care of patients with intracranial abscess
